meeting_annotations.speaker: Fik Brushett
meeting_annotations.transcript: metal cations, things like that. How many cycles do you want these things to operate as a sorbent? How do you replace stuff that's partially degraded, right? As well as sort of what is the format of the reactor that you want to use. That has some benefits as well, especially if the molecules are tethered to a surface rather than freely solubilized. meeting_annotations.speaker: Jenny Yang
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think you touched on something important which is from my point of view, which is why I wanted to start working on this is that I think it's underexplored. I think people have looked at thermal nucleophiles for thermal capture but not very many that are redox switchable. So part of it is is trying to attach something that's has a reversible redox couple near your nucleophile to see whether you can impact those properties. And to some extent, we've had sort of mixed results, but they do have to be close. They have to be closely coupled basically. You know, changing the redox potential one or two more bonds away is not going to give you the the changes in properties that you need to switch. So...
